Next, recall that we want f and T_3 to share the same function and derivative values at a = 0 up to and including the third derivative. For instance, one of the four needed equations is T_3'(0) = f'(0). What does our work in the preceding question tell us about the values of c_0, c_1, c_2, and c_3?

Having now determined the numerical values of c_0, c_1, c_2, and c_3, use appropriate comptuational technology to plot the function T_3(x) = c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 x^2 + c_3 x^3 along with f(x)=e^x, T_1(x)=1+x, and T_2(x) = 1 + x + \frac{1}{2}x^2 in the same window as shown in Figure.

What do you notice? For approximately which values of x is |f(x)-T_3(x)| \lt 0.1?

What if we wanted a fourth degree polynomial approximation to f(x) = e^x near a = 0? Based on the patterns you've observed in T_1, T_2, and T_3, conjecture values for the constants d_0, \ldots, d_4 for a function T_4 of the form T_4(x) = d_0 + d_1 x + d_2 x^2 + d_3 x^3 + d_4 x^4 that satisfies T_4(0) = f(0), T_4'(0) = f'(0), \ldots, T_4^{(4)}(0) = f^{(4)}(0). Add this function T_4 to your earlier work in Figure. What do you notice?

solution.p: Let f(x)=e^x and T_3(x) = c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 x^2 + c_3 x^3.

table.title: Formulas and values for f(x) and T_3(x).

li.p: Since T_3(0) = f(0), this means c_0 = 1. Next, T_3'(0) = f'(0) tells us that c_1 = 1. Using T_3''(0) = f''(0), 2c_2 = 1 so that c_2 = \frac{1}{2}. And finally, the last condition is T_3'''(0) = f'''(0), which implies that 6c_3 = 1, so c_3 = \frac{1}{6}.

We notice that T_3(x) appears to be an even better approximation than T_2(x) near a = 0 and that the quality of the approximation extends further.
The function f(x)=e^x, its tangent line T_1(x)=1+x, the quadratic approximation T_2(x) = 1 + x + \frac{1}{2}x^2, and the cubic approximation T_3(x) near the point (0,f(0)).
We can see the better approximation by T_3(x) in the figure, and if we do some computations, we can see that for certain x near a = 0, T_3(x) is closer to e^x than T_2(x) and that the set of x-values for which |f(x)-T_3(x)| \lt 0.1 is wider than for which |f(x)-T_2(x)| \lt 0.1. We found in Activity that |f(x)-T_2(x)| \lt 0.1 for approximately -0.9 \lt x \lt 0.8; here, |f(x)-T_2(x)| \lt 0.1 for approximately -1.3 \lt x \lt 1.1.

T_4(x) involves the term w_4 x^4. When we differentiate this function 4 times, we get 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1 w_4. Since f^{(4)}(x) = e^x, f^{(4)}(0) = 1, so 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1 w_4 = 1 and therefore w_4 = \frac{1}{24}. This means that T_4(x) = 1 + x + \frac{1}{2}x^2 + \frac{1}{6} x^3 + \frac{1}{24}x^4. Plotting T_4(x) along with the earlier approximations we see that T_4(x) is an even better approximation to f(x) = e^x and on a still wider interval.
